items.title: Graphic Design: What a Trip
items.abstract: For Caroline Baumann, of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, vintage type settings and luggage labels from her Swiss grandparents hold a special place in her heart.

items.title: Fighting for Light Amid Urban Noir
items.abstract: The director Allen Hughes paints New York a darker shade of noir in “Broken City,” which traces the moral education of a cop who has shot a man dead and is forced to turn in his badge.

items.title: Country Returns to City Radio: After 17 Years, a Home in New York
items.abstract: Nash FM, at 94.7 FM, will fill a conspicuous gap in the city’s media market and serve as a flagship for a multimedia engine that will promote the “country lifestyle.”

items.title: City’s Chief Medical Examiner Since ’89 Quietly Retires
items.abstract: Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, who had served since 1989, developed the nation’s largest DNA laboratory to help identify the victims of the Sept. 11 attack.
keywords: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York

items.title: Steep Challenges for a Chinese Eco-City
items.abstract: With 350 million people in China expected to move to cities in the next 25 years, Tianjin’s successes and growing pains are carefully monitored.

items.title: In Israeli City of Haifa, a Liberal Arab Culture Blossoms
items.abstract: The embrace of secularism, feminism and gay rights in the cafes and bars of this cosmopolitan city is creating a counterpoint to Israeli Arabs’ traditional conservatism.

items.title: ‘Design Thinking’ for a Better You
items.abstract: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: Recipes for Bright Lights, Big Cities
items.abstract: So many options for dinner tonight: pasta with broccoli and anchovy sauce, miso chicken, kimchi soup and more.

items.title: Sam Shepard Takes Stock of ‘Buried Child’ and the Writer’s Life
items.abstract: Mr. Shepard comments on his play, soon to have its third major production in New York; his upbringing; and the limitations he finds in his own oeuvre.

items.title: ‘Broad City’ Is Ending. Be at Peace With That. The Creators Are.
items.abstract: In a freewheeling interview, Abbi Jacobson and Ilana Glazer, stars of “Broad City,” explain why they ended the show and why they look forward to life without it.

items.title: Some Workers Need Jobs as Much as Builders Need Workers. Cities Connect Them.
items.abstract: In tight labor markets, developers and local leaders are using major projects to provide residents with careers in construction.

items.title: In Texas, Trump’s Visit Offers Two Views of a Border
items.abstract: President Trump used McAllen, Tex., as the backdrop for his border visit Thursday. It is a city of 142,000, a place of synagogues, country clubs and misperceptions.

items.title: To Save East River Park, the City Intends to Bury It
items.abstract: A plan to protect the Lower East Side from flooding was just rejected by the city, replaced with a drastic revision that costs twice as much but does not disrupt traffic.

items.title: Review: An Aching Ode to Jerome Robbins’s Lost New York
items.abstract: For this essential New York choreographer’s centenary, a Public Library exhibition full of the joy and anxiety of postwar Manhattan.
keywords: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

items.title: With Sensors on Streets, France Takes Aim at ‘Noise From Hell’
items.abstract: The French authorities are installing “sound radars” in some cities to detect and photograph vehicles making excessive noise, which they say is a public health hazard.

items.title: Russian forces are laying siege to the northern Ukraine city of Chernihiv, the mayor says.
items.abstract: Ukrainian forces are battling to keep some roads open, as Russia tightens its cordon around the battered city. “We are surrounded,” the mayor said.

items.title: Hidden Tampa: The Best of an Often-Overlooked Florida City
items.abstract: From a Buddhist temple reached by boat to a storied hotel and a speakeasy bar: a cheat sheet on what to do in this Gulf Coast city, which has found new fans during the pandemic.
